tit.cmt: 用語集の表記に合わせて修正 Murinan (a garden) → Murin-an Villa

sen.j: 無鄰菴（むりんあん）は京都府京都市左京区にある日本庭園を中心とする施設で、国指定の名勝。
sen.e: Located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, Murinan is facilities centered on a Japanese garden and is designated as a national beauty spot.
Located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, Murinan is a facility centered on a Japanese garden and is designated as a national beauty spot.
Located in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture, Murin-an Villa is a facility centered on a Japanese garden and is designated as a place of scenic beauty.
sen.cmt: Murinan → Murin-an Villa「名勝」用語集の表記に合わせて修正 a national beauty spot → a place of scenic beauty

sen.j: 1894年（明治27年）、山県有朋が小川治兵衛に京都の別荘として作らせた。
sen.e: Aritomo YAMGATA had Jihee OGAWA built it as his villa in Kyoto in 1894.
Aritomo YAMAGATA had Jihee OGAWA build it as his villa in Kyoto in 1894.
Aritomo YAMAGATA had Jihee OGAWA build it as his villa in Kyoto in 1894.

sen.j: 名前の由来は山県有朋地元にある「草菴」に隣家がない事による。
sen.e: The name originates in that there was no house adjacent to "Sosan (thatched hut)" in the home town of Aritomo YAMGATA.
The name of the garden, meaning 'garden without neighbours', stems from the fact that there was no house adjacent to "Sosan (thatched hut)" in the home town of Aritomo YAMAGATA.
sen.cmt: Meaning clarified for ease of understanding, spelling.
sen.e: The name of the garden, meaning 'garden without neighbours', stems from the fact that there was no house adjacent to "Soan" (thatched hut) in the home town of Aritomo YAMAGATA.
sen.cmt: 「草菴」統一リスト（その他 2009/10/26）に従い、クウォーテーションからカッコを出しました。読み（そうあん）にスペルを修正 "Sosan (thatched hut)" → "Soan" (thatched hut)

sen.j: 敷地内には茶室・洋館・母屋がある。
sen.e: A tea ceremony room, a western style building and a main building are provided in the premises.
There is a tea ceremony room, a western style building and a main building on the premises.

sen.j: 1903年（明治36年）に無鄰菴会議が行われた。
sen.e: The Murian meeting was held there in 1903.
The Murinan meeting was held there in 1903.
The Murinan conference was held there in 1903.
